CHOOSING COLORS

The huge advantage to this framework is the ability to easily swap out colors. I like ColorLovers, and use it to find good palettes but they are always hard to incorporate into my design. Here is the palette for this demo. Note: this element is a figure!

GRID

This is the grid. It is a modified verison of Toast by Dan Eden. There are excellent examples over on the project page if you need more info.

BUTTONS AND ICONS

Here are some examples of the buttons. These have hover, focus, and active states.

a.button

ALERTS, BACKGROUNDS AND COLORS

This framework uses classes to add the correct colors and backgrounds to your elements.

.alert.bg-primary.color-white
.alert.bg-secondary.color-white
.alert.bg-accent.color-white
.alert.bg-light.color-black
.alert.bg-dark.color-white

CODE & BLOCKQUOTE

Code and blockquote styles are predefined. Their features are part of the object-orientated part of the CSS styles.

code.bg-accent.color-white code.bg-primary.color-white code.bg-dark.color-white
Here is some text that would be wrapped in a blockquote format

.zebra-even table

FORMS

Forms have classes to manipulate them based on the screen size. This form has a mobile-full class. Which allows 100% form inputs on small screens. It also has a clear-inputs class which displays the inputs vertically.

SPECIAL CLASSES

These are some classes for an object based CSS approach

.visible-small
.visible-mobile
.visible-tablet
.visible-desktop

ICONS

Based on the icons in the TukTuk framework which are based on the Font Awesome project.

MODAL

Something you might need is a nice modal window for showing content. This window requires specific markup.

VARIABLES

This framework was built from scratch to use as many variables as possible. The reason for this is to easily allow customization. Here is the variables file for this page.

site variables file goes here
